posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I hope you're still here OP, because I have a lot to say on the topic.

I'll start with engines and transmissions.

4.3L v6 is basically the 5.7l v8 with two less cylinders. They get a little bit more fuel economy at the sacrifice of a lot power. If you can, try and get a 5.7L V8. You might occasionally, and very rarely find the 305 (5.0 L) V8 which is just a de-borred 5.7, its the worst of both engines, massively less efficient for not that much power gain over the v6.

Now, 6.2 N/A and 6.5 Turbo diesels are very hit and miss. I won't get into them here since there's a lot to say about them either which way or another.

Now, if gas cost doesn't matter to you, a 454 (7.4L) V8 is very good. tons more power then the 5.7, and only a little less fuel economy.

from 88-95, you had the TBI injectors, and in 96, they introduced the VORTEC fuel system. Basically, torque figures stay roughly the same, but since the engine can breath better at higher RPMs, it makes almost twice the horsepower.

Personally, I prefer TBI since these aren't fast trucks and the extra HP doesn't actually make a difference. Vortec heads tend to blow up easier then TBI engines as well, and TBI is so basic simple to work on, i prefer the extra piece of mind the reliability give you.

Don't let any stupid boomer talk you into carb swaping them either. any carb is going to be less reliable then a TBI. you're going to make less power, get worse fuel economy, and you've introduced more unreliable parts. And DONT put a "cold air intake" on it. They come from the factory with one. If you put one one, you're actually turning it into a hot air intake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26351267
carb swaping also comes with changing your fuel pump as well. TBI is a high pressure while the carb obv isn't.

if you want to build out a v8 in a gmt400, you need to complete the "fire triangle."

you need more air, more fuel, AND more exhaust. Meaning you need to either invest in a TBI spacer and chip upgrade, cams, and exhaust. (or if youre a poorfag, you get a bigger carb and swap it rather then work on the TBI)

putting a bigger exhaust will get you a little more HP, but you'll be moving up your peak torque RPM and loosing some torque. expect to lose about 30ft lbs of it and gain about 20 HP because of back pressure losses. Ultimately, a poor choice on its own.

just doing a TBI upgrade will yield only a gain of a few HP, and doing just a cam upgrade will just make you sound choppier.

doing just a tbi upgrade/carb and a cam upgrade you won't be able to push the fumes out enough. just exhaust and tbi/carb will make it run rich.

basically, unless you do all three, you're throwing money away for not real gain in power.


Now, transmissions.

AVOID 1995 MODEL YEARS
Its still a 4l60E, but since 95 was a bastard year for the GMT400 chassis (new interior, old powertrain still) but that also meant that year is a single year transmission type. 94 and before 4L60e's had 4 shift solenoids, 96' and later had 6, but good ol 95' had EIGHT. a lot of shops are clueless of this too. you'll take a 95' in for a tranny swap and they'll order the wrong one and either not hook it up correctly, or they'll realize they've fucked up, send back the wrong one, overpay for a new one, and charge you the return shipping on the wrong one and claim its the cost of the "muh single year rare transmission"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26351274
Now, interiors:
88-94 had the older boxier style. The radio is a non-stand DIM so if you get an aftermarket one, the stock radio slot becomes a cubby, and the single dim moves to where the optional casset/cd player was located RIGHT in the middle. These interiors were a lot easier to work on than the later 95+ ones, which their feature was introducing airbags.

and while rare, the old boxy interior did have a package you get two captain chairs and a center console. the old style interiors still had the older style thermal coupling 4x4 floor shifter as well. it was only the newer style interior that introduced the electronic 4x4 which were known to break. the nice thing about the older floor shifter one too, there's an inexpensive mod that lets you access the lower gear range without shifting into 4x4, meaning you get RWD with a low range which is really nice for backing up trailers.

really though, interior comes down to preference. 95+ is a lot better for drink holders, as the ones in 88-94 are lovingly called "cup throwers" rather then holders.

also back to transmissions, the 4L60e is a FINE transmission, don't let anyone tell you otherwise. the no.1 killer for them was people TOWING in overdrive (4th gear). The second most common was just leaving it in overdrive and it would gear shift between 4th and 3rd on 45mph-55mph backroads.

if you're towing or loaded down, use D
if you're going up a steeper hill on the interstate or see it coming up, use D
(D) is only to be used while unladen, on the interstate at speeds of over 55mph. Using cruise control and overdrive on the freeway WILL get you 16MPG, potentially even 18 if you're on stock tires, no lift, and have your airdam still, and thats with the 350 tbi and 3.73 gears.

on that note too, lets talk gearing.

if you want a gutless, but more fuel economy, get the "cruiser" 3.42 gears. 3.73 is jack of all trades and the most common one. 4.10 is for max towing but you'll kill your fuel economy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26351282
What i like about 3.73 is that in 3rd gear (1:1 ratio) is that at ~60mph on the stock larger tire size, puts your right at 2600RPM, which is the 350 TBI's max torque RPM, which makes highway towing really nice.

and while on the topic of rear gears, don't fear the G80 auto locker. The only reason they "grenade" is because bubba does too many burnouts, or hammers it too often while one tire is on asphalt, and one's still on gravel. i love mine and at 300k miles, it still looks pristine.

Also too, a 350 TBI can and will run on E85 if you really wanna be a weirdo. all you need to do is gap the spark plugs more, and advance the timing.

They're really great trucks OP. I love fords too but I just so love the GMT400 chassis. its imo the perfect truck.

I'm a poorfag making about $55K/year military disability (legit, destroyed back and shoulder) but I'm also a mechanic and have more classic motorcycles than I can reasonably use, a decent shop, home machine shop and tools out the ass.

Lead an efficient life, learn to wrench early (or late, or anyfucking time) then get good and your main problem will be too many vehicles because they spring up like mushrooms. Wrenching and DIY are such insane income multipliers if I were a millionaire I'd still do it besides it being huge fun. My home is paid for (bought cheap and DIYed) and my overhead is tiny.

Humans are a tool using species and YOU can do what anyone else can do. Everyone breaks shit learning. Press on anyway. Even professionals break shit now and then because no one is perfect. Just fucking DO it.
When I'm bored I get with my gearhead bros and work on their shit. We helped build each others shops. If you want it bad enough just decide then execute. I'm not the sharpest turd in the bowl but I persist.

>>26334248
I dont have a desirable cat worth stealing but if i did this is what i would do: There is a grade of tool steel called HSS or high speed steel. Its formulated and heat treated in such a way that it is extremely hard but brittle. Some drill bits are made of the stuff. You can also order long sticks of it in round, square, rectangle, whatever. It can only be cut with grinders and cut off wheels. Most cat thieves use a swazall. I would get some lengths of hss or even cheapo drill bits and weld that shit to the length of the exposed exhaust pipe wherever it is accessible with a sawzall. They may cut your exhaust pipe but as soon as they run into that hss "spine" (for lack of a better word) their saw blade will be toast, dull asf. The "spine" should be welded on top of the pipe or as high up as possible for difficult access with a cutoff wheel. More than likely the pos would give up and move on to an easier target leaving you with your expensive cat still in place. Why muffler shops havent come up with this as a service i do not know. Anyway thats my two cents fwiw. Thank you for reading my blog.

Idk, a P0117 is a code for the coolant sensor reading being 0V or close. Most of the time it means the coolant temp sensor is internally shorted though not always. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26337911
something is causing the misfire
if you swap coils/wires and plugs both to different cylinders, if the misfire moves to that cylinder, you know the problem is that component (for ex if you move the coil or wire from cyl 7 to cyl 8 and the code because p0308), you'll want to read the actual misfire count btw as it takes a quite a while to set a code if intermittent misfire
if you move the plug and coil/wire and the misfire doesnt move, you either have something wrong with the cylinder itself (bent valve, damaged piston ring etc), or something wrong with the wiring for that cylinder, or the ecu. you didn't bother to tell us what type of car it is so i can't really give you anything more specific

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26341672
Well, it sounds like you've had a confirmed ABS engagement before, so you know what it feels and sounds like. If it's the same or reasonably similar then it's the ABS. You'll need to bring it in to get diagnosed which any competent shop should be able to do.

If you don't think it's the ABS or you're not sure then you can visually inspect your brakes for anything funky. I've seen brakes that are right on the edge of worn out that only grind under heavy braking, but that wouldn't explain the pedal dropping which is pretty uncommon, and the fact that it only happens towards the end of a stop which is classic ABS/intermittent wheel speed sensor signal behavior

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26333365
Mk 3 Renault Twingo
My mum has one and I've used it a few times over the years
The engine in the back means the boot is very small, but the other day I moved a 50 litre fish tank and stand in the back (only just) so if you are hauling anything you have some space if you put the seats down.
With the engine in the back, it probably has the best turning circle of anything in it's class which makes parking easy and city driving a breeze
The seating position is also very high for such a small car which is nice
I haven't used it enough to tell you how economical it is, but my mum seems happy. In the UK we have emissions taxes on cars but it's on the lower end of the scale so it's either £0 or £20 a year.
It's also been reliable. The starter failed about a year after we bought it (late 2016), but that was replaced and there have been no problems since.
I actually really like it. I've been using it a bit as I'm in between cars, but the biggest downside is the engine. It's geared very high like a city car should be, but it's gutless so even accelerating up to 30mph (50kph) takes some time, and getting to motorway speeds is even longer. Wikipedia says 0-60mph is 14.5s and that seems accurate. If you have lots of motorway driving I'd consider something else, but if you only go on the motorway on rare occasions, it's not bad.

>>26331443
I have an '88 Cherokee 4.0, and with the new o2 sensor plugged in, I'll get a flat spot in acceleration a few times then it will go away until i restart the jeep again. Any ideas what's causing it?
With th o2 sensor unplugged, it never does it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26345910
check your MAF and check for vacuum leaks. when the o2 sensor is unplugged it goes into open loop mode so it just uses lookup tables for the mixture and doesnt use the actual readings. once the o2 is plugged in it goes into closed loop mode and starts adjusting the mixture based on the MAF and o2 sensor values. If the MAF is bad or there are vacuum leaks, it will run unexpectedly rich or lean based on what is happening which will cause problems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26346681
Jack up the front, grab the tire at 9 and 3 and shake. Sometimes you can see or feel play in the joints well enough by yourself either in the tire or putting your hand on the actual the rod itself while you shake the tire. Might want a second person to crawl under and watch/feel while you shake the tire. You can also check your wheel bearings and either strut mount (macpherson struts) or upper ball joints (double wishbone) by shaking at 12 and 6. Put a jackstand under the control arm and pry up on the bottom of the tire with a long prybar or long piece of wood to check the lower ball joint.

>>26348276
Short answer: no. The reliability and longevity of an engine is mostly due to proper maintenance and driving conditions. Under ideal conditions a properly designed engine can run indefinitely, and a built version would offer no benefit. Under worst-case conditions a built motor may last longer than stock, but billet and forged internals aren't going to save you from lack of lubrication, friction WILL win in the end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26350439
what year 700r4? ideally you want 1987 and up as it has the aux valve body and other fixes over previous years. In a performance setup I'd forgo the PCM lockup , wire a toggle switch with indicator and relay on brake switch. The PCM awill try best to engage lockup in 3rd and 4th which can create hunting, shudder and lug. A vacuum type 4th gear lockup kit may not work well with the supercharger and can still have issue with engine load lug say if your in 4th with tcc enaged and then encounter a hill. With a toggle you can just disengage and rev out 4th. A aux trans cooler would be recommended with this setup especially if not equiped and just using the internal radiator cooler.

suggest reviewing the ATSG 700r4 manual as the wiring to the solenoid vary
https://www.thirdgen.org/forums/attachments/transmissions-drivetrain/451360d1514830994-700r4-upgraded-pistons-th700r4-update-handbook.pdf

And, if this is really the worst position, what is recommended? Im young, inexperienced, and broke with very little to no expenses besides bills n food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306734
Most company driver hate is memes, with some truth mixed in. In general, if you take pride in your work and learn the unspoken rules (like don't take your 30 in the fuel lane, and say no to flip flops) you will be ahead of 80% of the company drivers most are upset about.

Get your first year in, and immediately go find a company that pays better and doesn't hire students. You will almost always find your pay doubles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
How do most company positions feel about taking a girl along for extended period of time? I’m not talking about like, every once in a while, I mean more like 80 to 90% of my over the road time with girlfriend in passenger.

Should I just be doing local or dedicated (which I’m certain are very few with my experience and age) ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306869
Not him, but am familiar with the industry... Most companies allow a passenger to be brought along, but you should get their OK first though, for insurance purposes.

What sort of work you do is up to what you like. Some guys like highway, some guys like local. Highway is a good place to start though for the experience. I lasted about two years highway before the novelty wore off, and have only done various local work since then. I value home time more than I value an easy cruise down the highway. But I never regretted that time spent on the highway... I went to places that I would've never seen before, and got paid for it. Met some interesting characters along the way also.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
>>26306889

I appreciate it. Just hoping May treats us good enough for our lives to get started. Ill see if I can’t convince them to let me run local after a year or so, like last reply said I value home time a lot as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
You know it is what it is... It's not all bad really. The minute you're running for them means you're now in control of your own situation, being actively hired and trucking. If you don't smash up their shit on a regular basis, keep on trucking for them while enjoying new sights & smells, but start tossing out resumes to outfits like USPS if you want big pay with more home time. Or operate the concrete truck... I made good dollars operating the concrete mixer for a season. With experience under your belt, more options will open up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
I have a friend who started at May, functionally he said it was a good company, they keep you moving and treat you ok. The downside is the pay is low (for the industry) you will keep 6-700 a week.

But like i said above, get your year in, don't hit anything and you will double your salary when moving to a local/regional gig that requires experience. For instance, my brother runs fedex and is getting 1200/wk minimum guaranteed pay for fill in work.

posts.name: EF
posts.com:
>>26330363
Okay I’ll answer these even though I’m not ur google machine.
1:I go everywhere.
2:the trailer is a product of regulations. A closed tandem axle is allowed 34,000lbs a single axle is allowed 20,000lbs. Axles 10 feet apart are considered singles. So the trailer can scale 40,000lbs.
3:yes the tires scrub. For slow tight maneuvering I have a switch in the cab that dumps the air from the rear axle and the trailer rotates on the front axle.

>>26350604
>I went up and down my neighborhood street in 1st and 2nd gear for the first time. Whats the best technique to switch gears without jerking too much?

Fair warning I'm a noob as well. Best technique I've found when you're just accelerating normally and changing gears is do it exactly like a car. You slip the clutch just slightly when getting back on the throttle and letting the clutch lever out. In a car, you don't change gear, let clutch all the way out, then get back on throttle. You slip it a bit to make a smooth transition. When you're hammering down, you don't feel the harsh transition and you're shifting so fast anyway. Going to take some practice to get it down, just like everything else. Any veterans feel free to correct me.

They are pretty easy to install, hardest part is routing the wires from the handlebars back to under the seat.
Make sure you leave enough slack to allow the throttle to rotate fully. Also make sure the wire coming out of the grip doesnt get in the way of buttons and your good.
The glue that comes with the grips is useless and your left grip will come loose when the heat it on. I reglued mine with epoxy and they havent moved since.

>>26351329
Don't know. For a while in the 80's some bikes had 16in fronts, and 18in rears. I suspect after some geo changes 17in was a good compromise size and so now all sporty bikes run them.
18in is common for retro or old bikes. 16in is just rare, some scooters or old bikes run it.
19in is used on some cruisers front wheel and I think some adv bikes.

21in is used on dirt bikes and chopper/cruisers.
15in is used as a rear tire on some cruisers. Smaller is scooter tier.

I find radial tires to be the big game changer vs bias ply's.

Back in the day, my parents had the first gen ZJ 98 Grand Cherokee with the 5.9L Magnum V8 and it had face ripping torque for its time, it was really sick but the transmission eventually exploded. Then they sidegraded (or downgraded) to the smaller Cherokee (non-Grand) XJ 4.0L I6 and even though it's a more convenient city car it's nowhere as comfy as the Grand Cherokee which had a significantly larger interior and MOH POWAH BB.

They both break down a lot because lol Chrysler brands but IMO only get the Grand Cherokee if you can get the 5.2 or 5.9 V8 and Cherokee if it's the 4.0L I6. The XJ is still really based though, it's a better modding platform than the ZJ Grand Cherokee but the ZJ has the way cooler engine.

My point was that it's a 4.5" standard, they didn't make a "114.3" just as a coincidence.

It's because the U.S. rebuilt Japan after WWII. We sent them machinery from GM and Ford. Harley Davidson even sent tooling to make HD's in Japan for the Japanese market.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26337885
I've repainted my wheels. But I didn't bother overhauling them.

They originally had powder coat on them, so I took it to industrial shop that cooked the powder coat off.
I then sandblasted them with glass beads. Since they were aluminum, I went ahead and used Alodine on the bare metal, then rattlecan'd Zinc Phosphate primer. The alodine is there mainly for corrosion prevention, not so much paint adhesion. You dont need alodine or the Zinc P. I used it because I had it on the shelf.
After the primer dried, I used a Rustoleum white. Not the high temp engine paint, because it was pretty shit, but just the regular stuff. The idea was that if I get any scuffs in the future, the touch up paint would be easy to acquire and match.

The reason why your valve cover didn't hold onto the paint was most likely because the surface was too smooth. You'll have to scuff it. Either blasting or using something like a scotch brite pad or fine sandpaper. Then clean with acetone. After you clean it, avoid touching it with bare hands.

What was the weather like when you painted? Avoid painting in high humidity. If it's hot outside, then the paint will dry before it even hits the part if you're spraying too far away.

https://www.cerakote.com/resources/knowledge-base/108/sandblasting-the-substrate-the-importance-of-a-correctly-etched-profile
We highly recommend using only #100 grit Aluminum Oxide or Garnet Sand, either will give the substrate a properly blasted profile for Cerakote application and performance.
Sandblast at approximately 80-100 PSI, blast profile should resemble a sand paper like finish.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26337885
These were stripped of some horrible black rattlecan shit. Used a combination of paintstripper, wire wool, steaming, jetwashing, wire wool, wire brush and stripdisk. Modern paintstripper sucks ass unless you can get the pro grade stuff with the old poisonous chemicals in it. They seem to have been sandblasted before, metal was heavily textured and pitted. You can see the texture on the lips, those are left bare metal. Took months of weekends laying coats of high build primer, waiting for it to cure and sanding back with multiple grits. Then standard primer, then several coats of generic part store gloss white. Then sanding out runs, keying the whole thing and more coats. You will hate your life. You will wish you never started. You will be unsatisfied with the results. You will spend more in tools, materials and time than it would have cost you to pay someone else to do it. It is totally possible though.

posts.com:
Is Midnight Club 3 the best arcade racer ever?
Pros:
>Unparalleled sense of speed
>difficult to master handling system that is extremely rewarding when you master it, especially with tail happy cars like the Viper GTS R
>diverse cities, that feel really lived in
>way more in touch with the racing scene in the era than it's competitors
>no bullshit story
>good difficulty curve
>great and fitting soundtrack
>graphics don't look horrible, but not as good as MW

Cons:
>lackluster vehicle list, most of the tuners are just muscle cars (in what world is a C5 Corvette or a Viper a fucking tuner? )
>Only a handful of JDM cars, the game is partially set in Tokyo for God's sake
>No one except the mechanics has any personality, including the drivers, a huge downgrade from MC2
>car models are total dogshit in compared to Most Wanted (see the Viper for a good comparison)

Did i miss anything? I genuinely believe that if it were released on PC it would be still popular today

>>26337453
I think the car list is one of the best that represents the era IMO. You've got some land yachts, oddball SUVs you don't often see in games from a Yukon Denali to an Infiniti FX (+the popular ones, too), oddball luxury cars such as the VW Phaeton and Lexus SC430, and even some concept cars such as the Dodge Super 8 Hemi, Cadillac Cien and Chrysler ME-412. There could've been a few more tuners, but it was 'DUB Edition' and going more for that blingy theme. V8 Dodge Chargers and Lotus Esprits are definitely not tuners by any means however.
The Tokyo setting was also added as an afterthought in Remix and it itself was a rehash of the Tokyo map in MC2, though I found it rather disappointing that you don't even win any Japanese cars there outside of the Nissan concept car (and the Infiniti G35 technically, though it's in USDM form)
The customization is still top tier, however. I love how the majority of cars offer bodykits all from real brands of the era, and how you can even mess with individual tire sizes to go bigger/smaller to your tastes. A full livery editor would've made it nearly perfect.

>>26338747
I got you brah. Look up ACTK-fr - I recommend them as the go-to for cars in general since they don't just collect and reupload them, but add LODs and fix some issues here and there, making them immediately better than what a lot of the original authors post since they can't bother to optimize their shit, specifically all the asshats that just try to sell their garbage on Patreon, not that there aren't good (free) car mods to be had on there and other similar sites. There are plenty of street cars and tracks on RaceDepartment, if you can't find what you're looking for on either of those sites, look up Totsugeki - mostly Japanese cars and better presentation of what to expect. Assettoland would probably be the next place to check, though IMO it's kind of a disorganized clusterfuck after it got shutdown like three times for sharing payware cars. As for people on Patreon: Dan Bucsa, MacedoSTI, VR driving, Jerry Wei/伯瑜 魏, DanielDi, Just Kapi, etc. You can find a bunch of cars and shit searching on jewtube too. I'd say don't bother with the Cut Up No Hesi servers unless you really want a specific car and have space, most of the cars in their packs are half-baked garbage, though their traffic pack I would say is the gold standard. Freeroam maps and driving with traffic? Search YouTube. There's a bunch now, though the best ones that I've tried are LA Canyons, Pacific Coast Highway, Union Island, High Force, and Shutoko Revival Project. You'll have to get into discord servers to get download links to a lot of content too. Touge Union and Kami Trick have some nice content floating around. Currently 2REAL is the best traffic simulation but it's singleplayer only. If you want to do multiplayer with friends with AI traffic, look up Assetto Server. Their documentation makes it simple, if you can't figure it out, you're a brainlet.

$640? You're looking in the wrong places. The G920 and G29 have regularly gone on sale for $200 ($50-$60 for the shifter) for years. Keep an eye on eBay and Goodwill/other online auctions, you can score those used or the older G27/G25 for under $200, just be sure to verify that it works first unless you're handy at repairing electronics. Considering some of the wheels on the market are 20 years old, I'd say they're built pretty well. If you are willing to get the G25/G27, try to go for the ones that have the shifter that can convert between H-pattern and sequential. And if it's not a motion capable cockpit with six degrees of freedom, it's a meme as far as I'm concerned, just plop the wheel onto your desk and call it a day. Desk too small? Buy a new desk or find one off the craigslist free section, or build your own faggoty static cockpit for under $100.

>>26341643
as i said the heavy v8 actually interferes with what is otherwise an extremely precise grand tourer
all the effort that went into making sure the v8 can turn at all simply means the v6 turns better, and the fact that it loses weight over the front axle specifically changes the dynamics for the better. the less powerful engine allows you to lay on it at the apex and steer through with the throttle without any tc intervention, the lighter chassis turns quicker and stops faster, and personally my hellcat diff swap is the cherry on top of a corner carving cake. i have ran with tuned widebody bmws and audis on the dragon, that fat bitch can fuckin scoot believe me.

on top of all that it's a class of car nobody else actually makes (cheap executive coupe) with a style unmatched by anything sold this couple of decades. there is nothing else like a chally wally. yes you could have a v6 camry or accord, probably cheaper, just as fast, but not rwd.
you could have a bmw 3-series, lighter, smaller, more powerful, better on gas, but it doesn't have the road presence of an actively exploding nuclear bomb, or you could have a camaro v6 with a stick and not be able to see behind or fit anything in your trunk, or you could have a mustang and be the reason nobody likes v6s, or you could have a miata and be endlessly hit on by mustang owners, etc
can you get a cool looking car that's simple, reliable, easy to maintain, not too new, not too old, handles good, seats more than two and hauls lots of stuff, that has literally no downsides or compromises compared to any other automobile, sold like a customizable burrito with an increasingly spicier selection of sauce to eat it with? a car that has worldwide acclaim and desire approaching ferrari levels yet it's just literally a rwd dodge stratus with a bodykit you can buy for 10k off cl?
yes you can.
it's the god machine, the chally wally.

>>26350946
Absolutely. CAFE calculates a vehicles 'footprint' by the length and width of all four wheels. The bigger that footprint is, the less they get hammered by CAFE. An F150 regular cab short box will see a greater CAFE hit than anything longer, so Ford will prefer to sell less of them, which is why you don't see them on lots and you'll most likely have to special order one, like I did.

Your a cuck who already lost a wheel once but i will throw your a bone like the neighborhood does to your wife
use hub centric spacer/adapter and rings. the rear should be easy to measure and find right size. the fronts can be tricky and you may need a different pair than the back if your spindle whatever covers it is more oblong than round. Now you still might run into a problem with older wheels not having a space for your oringal wheel studs to rest as the adapter will offset them. you might need like a 1-1.25 spacer to totally hide your original stud from the new wheel inner,
You ll then want also hub centric ring to fill gap between the hub of the wheel. plastic nylon whatever is fine. this will ensure the wheel is tight against your hubs.

>>26350409
Why are you asking a random maybe-cop online instead of contacting a lawyer? Cops absolutely don't know shit about the law, and this one might not even be from your state. You know tons of lawyers offer free consultations right?

Anyway just read the text of the code violation in your state and see if it applies to what you did. If it does, attend (online, potentially) court and take whatever plea bargain they offer you. If it arguably doesn't, attend court, plead not guilty, request discovery and get any evidence you can, and then argue your case as best you can. Or hire a lawyer to do all that for you (although solid chance they just show up in court for you and take the plea bargain). Traffic courts are a joke and the prosecuting attorney absolutely doesn't expect anyone to understand the justice system enough to put up a decent defense, and he also doesn't give a shit anyway. Other than the fact that you're de facto considered guilty until proven innocent in traffic court, it's relatively easy to get out of tickets if you're not blatantly guilty and know what you're doing (or do some research).

>>26348237
As a tech and car enthusiast I really don't care either way. Yet, I believe these big screen systems are poorly designed and ran by underpowered chips most of the time, offering a bad experience.

Tactile controls aren't appropriate while driving. I unironically believe the best controls would be 4 up/down/left/right keys (using your fingertips) + 2 ok/back buttons you push with your thumb, with everything being located where a bmw idrive wheel would be. That would be ultra-quick, as demonstrated by PC gamers. Something similar could be implemented in the steering wheel, using a small joystick you operate with your thumb and push to "ok" things, with a separate "back" button close to it you press with your thumb too. Of course, the whole interface should be optimized for such controls.

Ultimately, we live in an era where most people want multimedia stuff while driving. There's no going back and you need a screen for that. The thing is doing it right.

It's even worse than that.
Automatic License Plate Readers (ALPRs) are fucking everywhere now. Cop cars, utility poles, state lines, red lights, etc.
In the last several years many states have passed laws where you can now be fined automatically in the mail from ALPR data. They also store the data on every plate hit so a simple SQL stored procedure can instantly bring up everywhere someone has gone. In some states starting last year they can fine you for not having insurance from plate readers (speeding will be next), and some states are flagging out-of-state plates crossing state lines as potential vehicles to be followed / searched.
All in the name of 'saving police' since you can't fight a policeman if they don't even have to pull you over anymore.
The mass-surveillance tech boom has only started, cars having tracking devices will certainly be a part of it... and people will still somehow support it.

>”I think they’re putting their lives in danger,” said avid rider Doug Housman. “I think weaving in and out of traffic at any speed, whether you’re on a motorcycle or in a car, is dangerous. >Housman isn’t the only one who thinks so. Concerned drivers around Springfield say it’s about time laws applied to drivers on two or four wheels.

I understand your frustration, Taiyo and I look at other vendor's behaviors (and even my own) and try to avoid either repeating mistakes or going down a similar path someone else did. In my own opinion when it comes to non-OSG vendors, I wouldn't get my hopes up. This isn't a critique about Super Effective either, but for example if you encounter stores with pre-orders, poorly printed apparel being sold at ridiculous prices, various type of coomer products and etc without easy channels to reach them on their page, I wouldn't be surprised at the lack of support because they've made and spent enough money on other things and furthering their own business to give a shit about having a proper system for customer support. I'll repeat, this isn't a hit piece on them or any other vendor specifically, but you'll know what to watch out for when you see it enough times.

Again, I think keeping them is beneficial (unless for reasons including but not limited to the aforementioned for removal). Of course, you are welcome to discuss any other ideas and I will share them with Taiyo in a VC if he does not read them here first. If the complaints generated against SE are that overwhelming, we will take action now and in the future.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26335660
#1 is correct. Again, I'm completely on board with you. If enough people point out that there's an issue with someone or if there's evidence of foul play then we'll take care of it because we don't want people throwing away their money because we didn't clean up the site. Granted, the review system was an impromptu idea, there may or may not be better alternatives that I haven't thought out. A benefit of a review system is being able to see the frequency of getting a blem in the mail, consistent shipping times, re-stocks, etc. So even though a vendor may not fit the criteria for deletion for messing up a few orders or not having good QC, it'll be up to the buyer's discretion to use this information of how to spend their money. It's also provides the benefit of vendors not being able to hide negative reviews as a third party repository. I can assure you that if people wanted to say things about me and what happened last time, Taiyo wouldn't delete it and he would stop working with me if I suggested censorship to save a couple of bucks. My way of rectifying the whole order fulfillment mess is to completely eliminate stamped shipping and pre-orders to minimize lead-times as much as possible and I intend to prove that when the store re-opens and how I reveal products.

My personal take on your situation is that it's a mishap, Super Effective and Catch My Drift are basically one entity from my understanding and have a reasonably large following and put out a lot of product with what seems to be mostly satisfied customers. They also outsource the printing like many other vendors (including me), so there's always going to be blems unless you're the one handling production or paying them enough money to give enough of a shit.

posts.com: Is there any way to save a 4eat when is starts occasionally shuddering/hard shifting?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26326126
When was the last time you changed your ATF?
If never and the fluid is dark, change it with dextron 6 and a new filter and do a 3x3 flush with it (3 flushes 3 times with 3 new filters)
if it still happens your plastic pistons inside the transmission have most likely cracked and are leaking past the seals, I was going to get billet aluminum pistons made just before my red SF got totaled.
I managed to save my gold foresters 4eat with a 3x3 flush.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26326542
Do they really spec timing belts for euro cars every 100k km? In the US it's every 150-168k km.
But i'd pop your timing belt inspection cover (3 10mm bolts, left head on SOHC) because they also spec every 7 years so check for cracking or striping of the belt.
Really nothing much needs to be done at the first mileage service aside from the belt and maybe trans if its an auto, normally you can ignore the water pump for the first go around. But absolutely replace the timing cog located right next to it as they're infamous about burning the bearing out and taking out the timing belt.
side note on those cogs, for OE there's a few different part numbers but I've always gone off of what color the bearing was; orange, green and black. I've found that the green ones tend to last longer but that's bordering pseudoscience.
>>26326546
In my neck of the woods that's about average mileage for the 2.5 with memegaskets, at that age it more depends on how it was treated by its owner because it's well outside of the lemon period. The 2.0 isn't known for big problems like the 2.5 was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26335122
Oh also I meant to say that it might just be that the picture went funny, but it looks like the inside of that tire is worn smooth while the outside still has tread on it. If the other side is the same way, then your front toe is set too far out and that can chew through a set of tires pretty fast. In this case, a front end alignment will be well worth the cost.

If the other front tire doesn't look the same, then you might need a four wheel alignment. If Either of the rears look unusual then this is most likely the case. I'd be surprised if that were the only funky looking tire if there isn't a good reason in that tire's history. I would at the very least rotate them, or just swap the two fronts, and if the front driver's side wears that way again then there's definitely something way out of spec and you should have it looked at.

Gotta weld the center diff shut, and pop the cup off the outer CV joints to leave them in the front hubs so your wheel bearings don't sudoku. An STi R180 rear diff swap helps there.

>>26351098
I don't think this is good advice at all. The majority of good cars that are about 15-20 years old have actually climbed in price in the last 3 years. Old but reliable cars (like a corolla, civic, camry, accord, etc) have actually been an appreciating asset. This probably won't continue but the point is that a 10 year old car, if taken care of and a good make/model, will lose very little value over 5 years. Even less if it's 15 years old. A 2002 Corolla is essentially the same price as a 2007. Depreciation stops being significant after about 15 years or so.

On the other hand, a brand new car will drop in value like a rock over 5 years. Look at any 2017 car right now and compare it to what it was selling for in 2017. Even in this crazy market they're still down 30%.

posts.sub: Fuel Pump Failure, OR Something Else?
posts.com:
The Vehicle in question is a 2001 Toyota Solara v6. I'm not a mechanic, but I once worked at a lube shop so I understand SOME things about cars, and I'm quick to learn. That disclaimer out of the way, here's what happened.

Was driving on the highway to an appointment when suddenly I could no longer accelerate, the check engine light came on, as well as traction control intermittently while I pulled over to the side of the road. All lights, radio, air etc. Were working, I just could NOT give gas.

Turned off vehicle, tried to start, nothing. Had vehicle towed back to my place.

Vehicle turns over, but won't start every time. Try OBD 2 reader and get "Link Error". Looking at pin chart looks like pins are in wrong spot on the obd receiver. Have to self diagnose. Father-in-law and I decide it might be the pump after verifying the fuses aren't broken. Take pump out, fuel line has no gasoline in the line so no pressure released when we removed hose. Think it's a good sign pump needs replaced.

Replace pump, think we can hear it prime, but vehicle still wont start. Check pump, fuel is in the line this time.

Replace fuel filter next day. Old Fuel filter is not clogged and both ends of the line have gas. Try to start car. Still nothing.

Today we decide to test the pump and I noticed something that my father-in-law is writing off. The pump only turns on, when we try to start the vehicle, and won't prime when we put the key in the on position.

At this point i think it's a wiring issue, he thinks it's an ECM issue. I BELIEVE the ECM is behind the glove box, but my concern is if the pump is getting power only from starting the vehicle, wouldn't that be a wiring issue? Or could something have knocked loose from the ECM and needs plugged back in?

I'd rather not have to pay a mechanic 80-150 dollars to diagnose what's wrong, and then on TOP of that, paying the repair cost. Any and all help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26350089

That said, if the vehicle starts but then dies, would that mean the next step since we replaced the filter and pump, be the throttle body?

>>26350187
You have to check if the relays are engaging when you turn the key to the on and ignition positions. If you get it in ignition, but not on, you have a power interruption somewhere between the source and the key, as the ignition cylinder has 2 different contacts for ignition and on. It's likely the contact in the on position that tells the computer the key is on and sends power to the relay to run the pump.
It could be the computer, but you have tons of wiring to test before replacing the computer, or you might just spend all that money to have the same problem.

Look up the wiring diagram, if you're smart enough to read it, my EFI Toyotas have no connection between the ignition on switch and the fuel pump.
There is a relay connected to the fuel pump from the ignition START, and there is a relay connected to the fuel pump from the ECU or AFM, BUT NONE FROM THE IGNITION ON.

>>26350423
The ignition being on is seen by the car as the engine running. Power is supplied to ignition, fuel, and monitoring systems. If it is not, your car will shut off when the key moves from start back to on.
If you have the ignition set to on and you rotate the engine by hand, the spark plugs and injectors will fire. Do it fast enough and your car will start running.

Jesus fucking christ, the thread.

Fuel pump primes with koeo.
But.
If it doesn't prime but runs while cranking, THE ENGINE WOULD STILL START, it would just take a couple extra seconds of cranking.

Most vehicles run 39psi of fuel pressure at the test port.
Some run as high as 51psi (GM) because they overclock their injectors instead of using larger injectors to save money.
Check what the Nissan is suppose to be, install gauge and check reading.
Most auto parts stores have loaner test gauges.

>Is it true what they say about the P71's ECU "cop tuning" being more responsive?
The "cop chip" is an ongoing joke. The P71 and other panthers have the same engine/transmission/tune. The biggest difference is the P71 had different rear end options, higher ride height, extra oil/trans cooler, thicker sway bars, relocated gas tank, and some other small stuff.

lmao do you live in San Francisco or New York? I'm in the midwest and panthers are still cheap as fuck. My grand marquis has 150k miles, no dents, scratches, or accidents, no check engine light, everything working fine. No history of accidents on carfax etc. I couldn't sell it so I stopped trying. I had it listed for $3k on facebook marketplace a while ago. I was hoping to sell it and then use that money to buy myself an LS400, but the LS400 prices took off in the meantime. Unfortunately I only ever got 3 or 4 people who even messaged me about the car, and like half of them were mexicans who literally live over a thousand miles away in mexico.

The only thing I would advise though, is to get the lowest mileage for the price that you can. These cars are fairly reliable and bulletproof, but once they get closer to 200k miles is where a lot of things can go wrong if you haven't done preventative maintenance.

>>26346055
This is why I went C5:
-lightest Corvette with remotely modern design/manufacturing (some early ones were slightly lighter but they're built like an ox cart in comparison)
-modern enough to be reliable, old enough to be analog and TCS/Stability can be disabled with one press of a button
-proper 6 speed manual with the legendary T56
-enough power to spin all the way to 50 mph and possibly up to 75 depending on available grip
-unbelievably low CG, at speeds a crossover would feel like it was going to flip I can go +20mph though the same corner.
-one of the last Corvettes a normal human can work on without begging the dealer for help
-Pop up up and down headlights
-one of the most forum documented cars ever made, literally any peep of an issue and there's an autistic write up about how to fix it
-MPG isn't even that bad, most economy cars barely did better from the same era.
-front engine means it's more stable and predictable, MRs can be faster flat out but are also more likely to snap and kill you. Fine on a track with lots of runoff, less fine on the street. Front engine is also much easier to work on, which might be the biggest reason keeping me from ever getting a C8+.

posts.com:
>>26344372
Get your temp endorsement. Where I live, you just take a theory test and you get it.

After you get that, take your msf course. They're not a meme, and they also help you with lowering your insurance payments.

Don't get "good enough" gear. "Good enough" gear = cheap chinese knock off helmet, non-riding leather jacket, jeans, work boots, mechanic gloves.
Get a quality helmet, jacket, gloves, pants, and boots that are made for riding. There's plenty of youtube videos out there that'll walk you through what you need to look for in quality gear. The only thing I would say that some videos don't, is get an ece rated helmet. A lot of videos will say get a dot helmet, but that's gay. Get at lease an ece rated helmet.

Don't get more bike than you can handle. I'd recommend getting a bike that weighs less than 400lbs, and less than 50hp. Generally you'll be looking at 400-500cc bikes.

Also my opinion. The best bike to start off with are dual sports. They're basically dirtbikes that are street legal. Reason being is they don't compel you to act like a retarded boy racer, and they also are going to be cheaper for insurance. If you get a sports bike, you'll be paying out the nose for insurance.

After that, get your miles in, keep your ego in check, and don't act like a street rossi

It starts with mental health + physical health.

Eat lots of fiber, lots of unprocessed foods in general. Mind fog is the mind killer is the physical body killer.
After your mind is clear and ready you can anticipate many things on the road.

Absolute basics. Never take a curve you don't know too fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26344372
Dont speed (too much) . Look around. Check your brakes at least once a year. Change your tyres when it is time (5 ish years or when they loose too much tread) . Make sure your chain doesnt get caught on loose fabric like a tied backseat jacket, rope , saddlebag strings ecc.

Learn traction of surfices

Dry ashvalt having best traction, wet ashvalt is not that bad in terms of traction (unless you get a monsoon flooding the roads)

Worst traction is on : Oil(common in the middle of a lane at intersections ussually) and ice (32 farenheit) . They are to be avoided. Black ice (oil+ice ) is basically an instacrash

Watch out for, wet leafs, painted road surfaces in the rain, dust and various small debree (those wont instacrash you but will reduce traction severely and hard braking/ cornering could get you crashed

Do not do any hard manouvers untill your tyres are warm, that is how i dented my gastank (shouldnt take but 5 to 10 minutes of riding MAXIMUM)

Statistically : limb injuries do not resoult in statistically significant fatalities, but crippling injuries suck ass,
Head injuries account for 90%+ of fatalities , wear a helmet , possibly fullface, , the rest is torso injuries, jacket/ airbag vest.

Wear apropriate clothes for the season very cold: good gloves to prevent numb hands , it impacts your ability to controll the bike
Very hot : summer gear of sorts (hot weather riding is a science in itself its too comlex to write) , TIPPS: pack your pockets with ice, or use a hidration pack , good technical underwear (merino, spandex , ecc) can make a noticable difference in comfort. Brightly colloured helmet and clothes also make a noticable difference in hot weather comfort (white being the best at staying cool)

Try and have an escape route in mind when riding, remember if the situation calls for it you can lanesplit to avoid a crash. Lanesplitting saved me from a retard van driver once ( it was the first time I split lanes) .

Use your brain......

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26345725
Use your brain: if somebods driving is fishy, avoid them.
If you are blasting away at 200mph , nobody CAN see you with a !!!quick glance!!! of a rear view mirror. One moment you are 100 yards behind and in another you are 100 yards ahead.

Van drivers IMO are the on average most dangerous, no trucking education and a big car with poor rear visibility.

Start with a smoll lightweight bike .

My fav is an aprilia classic 50cc, aprillia rs 50, mash 50, ecc. Basically A 50cc with a clutch sn a shifter. They are just under or around 200lbs weight, fun, relatively inexpensive and you wont yeet yourself into the stratosphere with a wrong move.


You could however go bigger for a first bike but choose something that you can afford to fix if you drop it (a 125 cc,a 250cc, 300, 400 ,500) Remember the heavyer/ more powerfull the more difficult it is to ride. Things that help are a stiff frame, good brakes and suspention. Also if you are tempted to just let it ripp, you wont go 200 mph with a smoller bike. Also in my experience 15 to 25 hrsprs is more then enough for everything but the highway (or having a very heavy passinger)

Even a shit bike with functional tyres , brakes, and engine is safe as long as you do not start doing stupid shit


Be aware of the blindspot when passing. Deliberatly present yourself in the rear view mirror as long as possible while passing, if unsure prepare your thumb on the horn just in case , horn throws sound forward exaust throws sound backwards

Start slow. Home to local coffie shop/ store,

Home to a friends house,

Home to town centre

Home to a faster road and back

1 or 2 hours ride for fun outside of city limits or go to the next town over

Go on an adventure somwhere you have never been

>>26344381
Is the best advice here. I waited until I was 24 to start riding, and it's unironically one of the smartest things I've ever done. I know that answer sucks for you so here's two alternatives to just waiting six years:

1) Get a dirt bike, they're pure condensed fun, and the bike handling skills you learn there will be a great starting point to riding on pavement when you're ready. No license required if you're on private land or at an off road park.

2) If you really want to be riding in town, you can get an ebike. I've ridden one that can get you up to 30mph just on throttle, and will pedal assist you to the point you can ride literally all day at that speed. Bonus is you can do hoon shit with them (hop curbs, jump down staircases, ride through parks, etc) and not catch any fines. Mopeds and surrons fit this category as well.

Chances are you're going to ignore those two great points I made and get a bike anyways. In that case definitely take the MSF, wear gear, and start with a low displacement bike for at least a year. The faster ones will always be there for you later, and they're more fun to ride when you already have some experience, anyways.

1. Get actual training, MSF is a joke that doesn't teach you shit, do it, get your papers straight and then spend money on actual riding course
1 1/2. Make sure your course of choice covers stuff like emergency maneuvers, learn in advance how you can save your ass so you don't have to think about it when something goes wrong
2. Get proper safety gear, that shit really improves survivability
3. DO NOT BE RETARDED - 95% of might-kill-you moments are the result of riders being retarded or assuming people around them aren't. so just don't be a retard on the road, if you really really need to be retarded go find a big empty parking lot and retard there.
4. Be mentally prepared, know the risks, know the possible outcomes, weight it all in and try to prepare your head for the oh-shit moment so you lessen your chances of panicking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26344372
while >>26345550 is true, there's a lot you can do to reduce your chances of getting hurt. Watching crash compilations and normie riders in the real world has shown me that defensive riding can avoid most crashes. Crashes often involve:
>Riding too fast for road conditions or visibility
>Stunting or trying to show off
>Riding too fast for skill level
>Panicking and locking up, either just riding straight off the road or locking up the brakes and sliding out
>Clear dangerous scenario ahead, but rider either isn't paying attention or is too busy waving his arms around and yelling fucking cagers" to actually take evasive action. This is a big one. For some reason all these riders would rather make a stand against a 2 ton steel box with just their flesh and bones just because they may have right of way. Obviously they're going to lose that fight and get hurt. While the rider may not be technically at fault, he got himself into an easily avoidable collision. Half the time they're wrong about having right of way anyway.
>Riding in a way that puts them at greater risk of a traffic accident, such as not positioning himself for good visibility when approaching intersections, or even just going fast through intersections, or staying in blind spots of adjacent vehicles, or riding with a significant speed differential to traffic. While some of these are again not technically the rider's fault, they are his responsibility to avoid them because he's the one who's going to get hurt.

In short, consider your surroundings and view things from the perspective of other drivers. Never outride your line of sight or skill level. Nobody expects a bike to come flying over a hill or around a corner much faster than normal traffic, so they may be pulling out onto the road just as you appear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You get a motorcycle if you either:

1. Live in a small town
2. Live in rural area
3. Live in Japan tier place where no one drives like pieces of shit
4. You don't mind pain*

*To elaborate more on the last one, as some anon said above, tons and tons of crashes end up with the person "just fine" meaning that they either get a rib, arm, hand, wrist, or something minor broken.

Some people just don't seem to mind pain that much, they tolerate it, get better and hop on the motorcycle again, some people have little metal bars in their legs that had to be implanted after a crash, they don't mind and go ride again. Some people are like that, you could say they don't value their body at all, others would say they're "based" and don't fear. I personally don't like pain, I like my body, I fell a couple of times going fast with just fucking mountain bicycle, granted I didn't have protective gear, but it hurt, I can't imagine how must it hurt to actually break a leg/arm or having a more serious accident, just because either your wheel slipped, a drunk piece of shit decided to cross a red light, or whatever. It's up to you man, (If I were to buy one though, I would buy a cool scooter for city as they're comfortable as fuck and you seem to be more protected from a side crash)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26350764
>Toyota’s CRAWL system
I honestly think that Toyota has the solution to simulated 4WD systems with selective FWD biased AWD. The biggest problem is always wheel slip and selective brake application does fine in most cases in controlling that. It offers a level of control that isn't possible with a driver.

With the right control algorithms, it'll likely replace 4WD in consumer applications, relegating full time 4WD/AWD and lockers to hobbyist/specialty applications. Now that cars don't have to navigate terrain blind with wheel speed, yaw, pitch rate sensors, they'll probably integrate their radar and camera systems to scan its surroundings. I can't imagine how nightmarishly complex a system like this would have to be, but the compute capacity for industrial computation is there. I would wager that CAN-FD standard does not have enough data throughput to support that right now, and a new ISO standard will have to be implemented for the high data throughputs that are necessitated for even basic things like a truly intelligent, terrain-aware 4WD/AWD system, let alone fully autonomous driving. Automakers had better get very good at sealing electrical components, and also add in a fuck ton of grounding redundancies that don't involve braided copper straps (LOOKING AT YOU GM), otherwise these systems will fail in incredibly stupid ways.

With that said, there will always be holdouts that will prefer the mechanical systems, and they will have their place. Personally I think the best solution always has a failsafe. Most applications won't need it, and therefore won't have it.

The reason chains are losing out to belts is that chains stretch, and when they do, cam timing changes. And if the car won't meet Euro emissions with a stretched chain, they will not be approved for sale.

in general gasoline engines are easier to work with and belt driven engines are also easier to work with

It's the unfortunate reality of the modern economy, a "middle class lifestyle" by traditional metrics, or the lifestyle that a typical worker would have lived back in the 60s and 70s is no longer achievable for most of us.

Aus is in a bit of a weird spot right now though desu. We have real estate prices that are well beyond that of North America and even the UK outside of London, but our wage growth has been pretty bad for about the last decade. We were pulling better salaries than the Yanks for a while but their wage growth has been phenomenal compared to us so they've caught up with high incomes but far cheaper real estate.

The end result is that we're left trying to punt a far higher proportion of income into our mortgages and rent leaving less disposable for hobbies and fun shit.

>>26346358
So, I love it. But it is the performance trim (GT PE) with the racing seats, large tires, Brembo brakes etc.. The lower priced trims are fine, but they are more like a Model Y or other EV SUV than a performance car.

It is definitely my garage ornament / weekend car while my beater SUV remains the car for errands and daily driving. The Mach CAN be a casual cruiser but it's really built for speed and aggression.

Most impressive is the car tech and driving experience. I never though of Ford as a strong UX designer (remember SYNC?), however it feels like they REALLY took time to re-think what a car should be (and rip off everything Tesla does right). It's a joy to drive this thing around, super intuitive. Only real beef I have is the AC controls are terrible, but they've just pushed a hotfix to adjust this.

So my verdict would be —it's a decent daily driver family SUV in the lower trims, but I'd go Model Y for that. As a high end performance EV it is the best I've seen sub-$100k. (And frankly I think it look cooler than Taycan and GT RS eTron)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

>>26264308
The Taisan F40 got auctioned off a couple of years ago and went for roughly $1 million.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Taisan F40's History

The JGTC (Japan GT Championship) started in 1994 and it laid the foundation for what was to become Japan's top racing category, Super GT.

One of the cars that received particular attention in Japan’s rich racing history was a Ferrari.
The Team Taisan Star Card F40.

At the time, the Italian GT Championship saw European dream cars such as the Porsche 964 Carrera RS and the Jaguar XJ220 line-up against each other. But when Yasutsune Chiba, the head of Team Taisan, came across an article in a magazine about how the F40 was dominating in Europe, he couldn’t help but dream of the F40 racing around Japanese circuits.

Chiba immediately bought an F40 and showed it off at the Fuji Speedway for the opening round of the JGTC season. The red body-coloured supercar was, of course, the talk of the race fans and drew a lot of attention. At the time, however, F40 racing parts were hard to come by and the car had to be driven in a virtually stock configuration. Despite its reputation, the F40 struggled to keep up with the other teams, who had built their cars with a wealth of experience.

However, for Chiba, running the F40 in a Japanese race series meant a lot to him and he refused to give up, improving the car race by race. This gradually paid off and they took pole position at the 4th round in Sugo. The team then brought in Oscar Larrauri, a former Italian GT Championship driver, to drive the car and team to victory.

In 1994, in the final race of the season, held at the Mine Circuit, the F40 made a spectacular start and took the lead, but the 962C, also from Team Taisan, was following closely. A fierce battle ensued between the two cars, but in the end the F40 took the chequered flag in 1st place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They ended the 1994 season on a strong note but the following season however, the F40 was unable to perform to its full potential due to the full scale support for Japanese works cars and the introduction of new regulations. As a result, the F40’s victory at Mine in 1994 was its first and last one in JGTC.
But the spectacle of this beautiful car speeding around a Japanese circuit, made possible by the enthusiasm of Team Taisan, has left a lasting impression on many race fans and became a legend that will live on forever.

As a casual fan of the shows, I don't have personal opinions, but I can present arguments for both sides.

One argument in favor of "Top Gear USA" being better than the original "Top Gear" is that the American version had its own unique flavor and sense of humor that differentiated it from the UK version. The American hosts brought their own personalities and perspectives to the show, which made it entertaining in its own right.

Additionally, "Top Gear USA" had access to a wider range of cars and locations than the original, which allowed for a more diverse range of challenges and reviews. This added an extra level of excitement to the show as viewers were able to see a wider variety of cars being put to the test.

However, it's also worth considering arguments in favor of the original "Top Gear." The show has been on the air for over two decades and has built up a strong following of fans who appreciate its humor, format, and personalities. The original "Top Gear" was also able to attract a number of high-profile guests and showcase some of the most impressive cars in the world.

In conclusion, whether "Top Gear USA" was better than the original "Top Gear" is a matter of personal opinion, as both shows had their strengths and weaknesses. Ultimately, what makes a show good or bad is subjective and depends on the individual viewer's tastes and preferences.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26347325
They're cheap at pull-a-part yards and easy to harvest. Self and bro pull 5.3 and 6.0 in a couple of hours by recip sawing the frame rails on vans and trucks. There are plenty of 4.8s because no one wants small engines and since the 4L60E trannies die long before the engines it's easy to find good ones. Don't bother with anything rusty or nasty or flood damaged as engines abound especially if you go 4.8. Once the work is done you could do a 6.0 drop-in but a 4.8 would be a great fit for an S-10.

LSDroid will swap .bin files and Universal Patcher mods them easily. I use an OBDX VT and a Fire 10 (2021) bought for the purpose but phones will do. Make a bench harness out of one "blue" PCM connector and an OBD connector (cheap online or harvest with a blue PCM connector from another vehicle.

Get ALL the harness you can harvest and get the drive-by-wire pedal. We bring a shitload of black zip ties to wrap the harness to the engine. Get the fuse box. When you pay for a complete engine be damn sure you get one. That includes any modules connected to the engine harness. Get all the hardware you remove too. We bring a modded garden wagon with solid tires packed with tools.

Diablo Auto Dismantling blades are love.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26347325
More LS donor raep:

We rotate engines by the damper bolt when examining them and use a bright light down the oil filler. We have several sets of these to stabilize our engines in transport and bolt them on while the engines are hanging off the forklift:

https://www.amazon.com/Chevy-LSx-Engine-Storage-Stand/dp/B01N7W87BH

You can do the complete LS & tranny pull with fairly few tools. We bring 3/8" and 1/2" cordless impacts and the usual breaker bars and cheater pipes. While a good recip saw can cut the front off a truck or van on one battery and using only one Diablo blade, buy the blades by the box and bring two recip saws if you have smart help. With frame rails severed the torsion bars control the drivetrain when it tilts forward. A very useful tool is an angle head electric ratchet. We have 1/4" and 3/8" drive. The Harbor Freight long neck angle head 3/8 drive fits so many places we both bought one and my bro leaves his 3/8 Milwaukee at home. Long, very long, and short extensions are your friends. So is a set of metric six point 1/4" drive sockets and ratchet for many small jobs. If you've not done much salvage remember it's customary to cut out long seat belt sections to tie (firmly!) as engine lift slings if you don't own commercial ones.

You could pull and sell LS (and trannies, 4L80Es sell easy as do good 4L60Es which are not common) to pay for your own project and just keep the best engine for yourself.

pull-a-part yards sometimes place the support rims (junk rims welded together) too far forward for balance reasons. We put extra weight in the very back of the SUV like two or three wheel and tire assemblies so salvage staff can move the supports as far back as possible.

Put your truck to work making you money before modding it. The way to get toys is use your wrenching skills to make toy money. It's easy to drown in trucks and parts if you have room for them.

>>26323776

Audi and Subaru both committed the entire brand to the set up. Subaru uses compact boxer engines to reduce the weight and distribution of that weight. Audi intially wanted a 4 cylinder as well to keep weight down and a 6 cylinder was too much weigh too far forward so they ran 5 cylinders for a very long time. Then they developed very small compact engines to reduce the effect. The current V8 in the RS6 is shorter than the old inline 5 and cast out of aluminum.

They also have innovated the transaxle to allow the engine to sit more rearward than before so the weight distribution is more around 54/44 than the older 61/39.

Audi and Subaru do not get a pass. They get mocked all the time for the Achilles heel. But they’re significantly better than the acura situation which has no means to addrsss the problem, and really no need too since nobody expects an Acura or Honda ti be fun to drive

>>26327489
>fuckin dope. what was it like?
Had it from 2013 to 2022. Honestly it was a great car so long as you kept on top of it. Mine was in kind of rough shape and needed a motor rebuild when I bought it which is did in the first year. After that it was my daily driver until about 2018.

When I was driving it every day it was great. I had weird issues like when I needed to have the computer replaced because the sauder started coming apart.

The Problems didn't really start until I changed jobs and suddenly had a commute that was 30 miles instead of 5 and involved driving on the busiest parts of the freeway and downtown. I bought myself a Saab for $1500 and the 944 turned into my "weekend car"

Then I moved and it had to go into storage and just started to rot from lack of use. I finally let it go to a guy who was working on my mom's house last summer because it was his favorite model of Porsche. I figured it was better going to a good home than rotting away in a storage unit because my apartment wouldn't let me park 2 cars and the office complained about it being "loud"

If you have any intention of getting a 944 do the research that I didn't when I bought mine and wait until you find one of the at least decently kept ones. Otherwise be prepared to sink a grand a year into all the random shit that will break that you will never expect.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26332122
that's me, what do you need to know?
there are guides all over the place, but the main thing is access. you HAVE to permanently damage something, but what you actually damage is your choice:
>go through the wiper blade motor / battery area and have to destroy the baffle housing itself
>go through the dash and destroy the vent ducting (route i took, see the huge gashes in the vent and the taped column of plastic held down by painters tape)
in my picture >>26327489 you can see the metal baffle. well, that's one of two baffles. the one you can see if the diverter for vent directionality. the other is just to the left of it and diverts air through the heater core.
you have to do both. i used Gorilla's flex seal competitor tape since it's so wide and kinda soft. i poked little holes all over it to replicate whatever Porsche was thinking by using permeable foam instead of a solid aluminum baffle. maybe the porous nature of the foam keeps the servos from slamming when the baffles fire under fan pressure or something.

>pic for bumping

Couldn't turn down a stupid inexpensive 987s last year from a friend. It does have oiling issues after autoxing with sticky tires and aggressive driving. It ticks for 30 seconds or so after a run. So I'm just driving it for fun to compliment the race car for the next year or two as I setup my shop with a lift. Then I'll sell the low mile M97 and swap in another engine, likely audi 4.2 v8.

The chassis and steering are magical for what it is, the brakes are fantastic even if the pedal is a little spongy. The Gearbox is passable and shifter is meh. The engine feels pretty decent driving it around making some nice noises and the response change around 5k rpm feels like german vtec. If it didn't have oiling issues or eventual bore scoring I'd definitely keep the engine and do some bolt ons.

>>26350250
>Are you racing?
Effectively, yeah (endurance).

Motorcycle oils have to lubricate the engine, gearbox, and clutch, so they shear down much quicker than car oils, which only have to lubricate the engine.


I've never used Valvoline in 20W-50 form, but I've found Valvoline 10W-30 and 10W-40, along with Castrol, to be by far the worst performing oils I've used. I have no idea why. They just don't last before friction becomes too much. Even some bespoke blender oils perform better.

Sadly because the legacy car makers have learned it is more profitable for them to not make PHEVs, and instead sell functionally short-range BEVs to commuters in order to segment the market.

If anyone was selling a PHEV that could compete against the Tesla Model 3 Performance for the price, I'd be first in line to buy one, but for me the occasional mild inconvenience of a 10 minute fast charger stop caused by insufficient infrastructure investment in my area is worth the driving experience the other 99% of the time.

>>26348113
Pay with your card at the pump, tap to pay is optimal. Follow instructions at the pump and refuel the car, simple as. Make sure you choose the right octane rating (most likely regular unleaded) and the right pump, don't grab diesel if you don't have a diesel car.
If you have to pay with cash:
1) Take note of what pumo your car is at
2) Go inside to the cashier
3) "X dollar amount on pump Y please"
4) Pay, go back to your car to pump
5) If what you pump isn't as much as the money you gave the cashier, go back inside and ask for change on whatever pump you were at

Sure. Work up to the whole sequence by practicing individual parts. Like practice swerving to avoid an object. Practice braking before an object at increasing speeds, practice going quickly without losing control. Just have to get your monkey brain trained to do it without overthinking it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26348137
Reliability tends to follow a "bathtub curve" where failures happen more often right at the start (due to manufacturing defects), drop down to a steady state for most of the bike's life and then increase again late in its life as things wear out. By buying a demo bike which has already passed the initial failure period, you could actually get a bike which presents as more reliable than a brand new one.
The counterpoint is that it wouldn't have followed any sort of a planned break-in period, but in many cases it might actually be broken in better than the average rider would have done. Test rides don't take very long, and they go through a variety of slow and fast riding conditions - which is exactly what you want for a break-in period.
So I say go for it, particularly if you can get a good discount on it. You might even end up with a better bike than otherwise.

I'm gonna tell you the real reason, it's because they needed a car to compete in ALMS. They had the F1 inspired S85 V10 engine from the E60 M5 and cut two cylinders off of it and stuck it in the E9x. They were running V8s in the M3 GTRs before, but porsche lobbied them out because they weren't producing enough road homologations.
This wouldn't happen with the next M3 because the factory car would come with a V8 which allowed them to run the P65 within the rules. By the time GT3 had succeeded GT2 the M3 was replaced by the Z4 GT3, which ran the same V8 engine but never made an appearance in any road models.
